I.  PROPOSAL 
1.  Conversion of $150 million into a tranche to finance project 2 of the Green Power 
Development  and  Energy  Efficiency  Improvement  Investment  Program  in  the  Democratic 
Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka is proposed for Board consideration.1 
 
II.  BACKGROUND 
2.  Sri Lanka has a national investment program including sector investments that are 
based on the National Energy Policy and Strategies, which includes a sector road map, a long-
term investment plan, and policy and reform measures.2 By 2020, the government intends to 
(i)  increase power supply capacity and reduce generation cost, (ii) increase the share of energy 
supply from nonconventional renewable energy to 20%,3 and (iii) reduce network losses to 10%. 
The 20% increase in power generation from nonconventional renewable sources will add to 
29%  (2014)  of  conventional  hydropower  generation  and  will  ensure  that  in  the  future  a 
substantial portion of electricity is produced by clean energy sources.4 
 
3.  The multitranche facility (MFF) is financing part of the government’s energy investment 
program that was estimated at $4.8 billion for 2014–2020. The MFF was designed to support 
the green power development and energy efficiency improvement portion of the government’s 
energy  sector  investment  program  by  (i)  financing  hydropower  development,  (ii) expanding 
transmission and medium-voltage infrastructure to improve network efficiency and enable power 
evacuation  of  renewable  energy  in  the  system,  (iii) piloting  innovative  demand-side 
management technologies, and (iv) supporting capacity building and project management. 
 
4.  Through a periodic financing request dated 19 August 2016, the government requested 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) loans totaling $150 million and a $30 million equivalent loan 
from Agence Française de Développement to be partially administered by ADB to finance the 
project  2  outputs:  (i)  transmission  infrastructure  enhanced,  (ii)  medium-voltage  network 
efficiency improved, and (iii) demand-side management for energy efficiency improved.5 The 
impact of project 2 will be increased access to clean and reliable power supply. The outcome 
will be enhanced system efficiency and reliability. 
 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE ON ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT 
5.  The proposed tranche is classified under environmental impact category A under ADB’s 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).  The  220-kilovolt  Mannar–Nadukuda  transmission  line 
involves  power  evacuation  from  planned  300-megawatt  wind  farms  and  passes  through  a 
Ramsar wetland area for 7.5 kilometers.6 The project-affected area supports critical habitat. The 
project may have the potential for adverse impacts on the Ramsar wetland and the migratory 
and congregatory water birds that the wetland supports. An environmental impact assessment

2    
(EIA) including an environmental management plan (EMP) was prepared to assess the potential 
adverse environmental impacts.7 The EIA was informed by 2-year avifauna and marine fauna 
surveys in the affected area. Avian collision risk assessment for the transmission line and the 
wind farms, as associated facilities, was carried out. Mitigation measures are proposed in the 
EIA and EMP to minimize habitat and species disturbance as a result of construction and 
potential bird collision with the overhead transmission line. Implementation of the biodiversity 
management plan will ensure no net loss of biodiversity. Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), the 
executing agency, has committed to undertake further assessment and manage the impacts 
and risks of bird collision with wind turbines by curtailment during the breeding and migratory 
season if necessary. The EIA was disclosed on ADB’s website on 7 July 2016. 
 
6.  Potential environmental impacts of other transmission and distribution infrastructure are 
site  specific;  mostly  temporary  during  construction;  and  readily  mitigated  by  adherence  to 
national and international environmental standards, design criteria, and management practices 
as  set  out  in  the  EMP.  Sensitive  ecosystems  will  not  be  impacted.  Initial  environmental 
examination reports including relevant EMPs were prepared to mitigate the potential adverse 
impacts and disclosed on ADB’s website on 19 August 2016. The demand-side management 
output  will  have  minimal  environmental  footprint.  The  project’s  environmental  safeguard 
documents were prepared in compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement, the MFF’s 
environmental assessment and review framework, and Sri Lankan environmental regulations. 
 
7.  Public consultations on the transmission line and the first phase 100-megawatt wind 
farm  were  conducted  with  local  communities,  government  authorities,  and  nongovernment 
organizations, including ornithological societies, and their feedback was taken into account 
during project design. Public concerns were identified in the EIA, and mitigation measures were 
incorporated  in  the  EMP.  A  grievance  redress  mechanism  will  be  set  up  at  project 
commencement. All complaint-related documentation will be summarized and become part of 
the environmental monitoring report that will be submitted to ADB. If the grievances cannot be 
addressed through the grievance redress mechanism, the complainant can seek legal redress 
of their grievances in appropriate courts. Corrective actions will be taken for unanticipated 
impacts and inadequate safeguard implementation. Consultations with project stakeholders will 
continue through the pre-construction, construction, and operation stages. 
 
8.  CEB has experience in implementing ADB-financed projects, and it established a project 
management unit for the tranche. CEB will retain qualified and experienced external experts or 
qualified  nongovernment  organizations  to  verify  monitoring  information  on  the Mannar–
Nadukuda transmission line. Contractors will be required to comply with the EMP during the pre-
construction and construction stages under close monitoring of the external experts and CEB. In 
case the implementation of EMP measures is not satisfactory, the external consultants will 
recommend actions to enhance environmental compliance. CEB will provide environmental 
monitoring reports to ADB on a quarterly basis while works are ongoing within the Ramsar area 
and semiannually thereafter. These reports will be disclosed on ADB’s website. 
 
IV.  RECOMMENDATION 
9.  The President recommends that the Board authorize the conversion of $150,000,000 
into a tranche to finance project 2 of the Green Power Development and Energy Efficiency 
Improvement Investment Program in the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka.
